## üìã Investigation Plan

Based on your brief and the sources you provided, here's my investigation plan:

**Investigation Topic:** Indian defence

**What I'll Investigate:**
- What are the current capabilities and strengths of the Indian defence forces?
- What are the major challenges and threats facing Indian defence?
- What are the recent developments and procurements in Indian defence?
- What is the defence budget and expenditure of India?
- What are India's key international defence partnerships and their implications?

**Sources I'll Gather:**
- Official government reports and press releases (Ministry of Defence, Indian Armed Forces)
- Reputable national and international news agencies and defence journals
- Reports from defence think tanks and strategic analysis organizations
- Data and analysis from international organizations focused on military affairs (e.g., SIPRI)

**Your sources analyzed:**
No sources were provided by you.

**Mode:** Detailed Inquiry
**Estimated Time:** 10-20 minutes
[PLAN_APPROVAL_REQUIRED]

sources_accumulated.title: Ambition vs Reality: The Paradox Of India's Defence Spending
key_claims: India aims for defense self-reliance but still heavily relies on foreign suppliers for critical technologies.
The private sector's role in defense manufacturing is expanding.
Bridging the gap in self-reliance requires sustained investment in R&D, a deeper industrial ecosystem, and efficient procurement.
sources_accumulated.summary: The article discusses India's ambition for defense self-reliance against the reality of its dependence on foreign suppliers for critical technologies. It highlights the growing role of the private sector in defense manufacturing and the necessity for sustained investment in R&D and a robust industrial ecosystem to achieve true self-reliance.

sources_accumulated.title: U.S.-India Divergence and Convergence on Defense Operationalization Concepts | Council on Foreign Relations
key_claims: The U.S. and India have a strong defense partnership, particularly regarding China, but have significant differences in defense spending, civilian governance, and industrial independence.
These divergences need to be addressed to achieve a deeper defense partnership.
The article focuses on the "what, where, and how" of deterrence coproduction, categorized into capability, geography, and interoperability.
sources_accumulated.summary: This article explores the U.S.-India defense partnership, highlighting both their alignment in countering China and their fundamental differences in defense spending, civilian oversight, and industrial autonomy. It suggests that understanding these divergences is crucial for deepening their defense collaboration and overcoming obstacles.

sources_accumulated.title: Don't Call it a Comeback: Why US-India Relations are Due for a Rebound
key_claims: The 2025 Framework for the U.S.-India Major Defense Partnership elevates defense as a top priority in their relationship.
The agreement explicitly focuses on deterrence in the Indo-Pacific, with an implicit shared adversary (China).
The partnership is deepening in advanced domains like space, cyber, and AI, and encourages co-development and private sector collaboration through initiatives like INDUS-X.
sources_accumulated.summary: This article highlights the strengthening U.S.-India defense partnership, solidified by the "2025 Framework for the U.S.-India Major Defense Partnership." It emphasizes how defense is now a top priority, with a shared goal of deterrence in the Indo-Pacific, implicitly targeting China. The agreement also focuses on advanced domains like space, cyber, and AI, and promotes co-development and private sector collaboration through initiatives like INDUS-X.

sources_accumulated.title: India‚Äôs Defence Diplomacy: Projecting Power through Military Engagements and Training Initiatives
key_claims: India employs defense diplomacy to project power via military engagements and training.
Resource constraints (financial and material) limit the scale and sustainability of India's military engagements.
India's capacity-building efforts remain modest compared to China's due to these limitations.
sources_accumulated.summary: This article discusses India's defense diplomacy, focusing on how it projects power through military engagements and training initiatives. It highlights challenges such as resource constraints (financial and material) that limit the scale and sustainability of India's military engagements and keep its capacity-building efforts modest compared to China's.

sources_accumulated.title: Union Budget 2026 - Defense sector Highlights
key_claims: India's Union Budget 2026-27 significantly increases defense allocation by 15.18%, reinforcing self-reliance and modernization.
Capital outlay for defense surged by 22% for capability enhancement and procurement of next-generation platforms and infrastructure.
The budget demonstrates a commitment to indigenous defense production (reaching INR 1.54 lakh crore) and investment in future-focused technologies.
sources_accumulated.summary: This EY report highlights India's Union Budget 2026-27, emphasizing a significant increase in defense allocation (15.18% over last year's Budget Estimates), reinforcing self-reliance and modernization. Capital outlay surged by 22% for capability enhancement and procurement of next-generation platforms, while revenue expenditure increased by 17% for operational readiness. The budget also shows a commitment to indigenous defense production and investment in future-focused technologies.

sources_accumulated.title: Security and Defence: EU and India sign security & defence partnership | EEAS
key_claims: The EU and India have signed a new Security and Defence Partnership.
This partnership will be implemented through an annual EU-India Security and Defence Dialogue and aims to strengthen existing cooperation.
The partnership is a key component of the new Joint EU-India Comprehensive Strategic Agenda, focusing on shared challenges and threats.
sources_accumulated.summary: This article announces the signing of a new Security and Defence Partnership between the EU and India. This partnership aims to build on existing cooperation and will be implemented through an annual EU-India Security and Defence Dialogue, supported by thematic exchanges and consultations on shared challenges. It forms an integral part of the new Joint EU-India Comprehensive Strategic Agenda.

sources_accumulated.title: Boosting U.S.-India Private Sector Defense Industrial Cooperation
key_claims: India is actively seeking to diversify its arms suppliers, moving away from its traditional reliance on countries like Russia, driven by the "Make in India" initiative.
The U.S.-India Comprehensive Global and Strategic Partnership offers avenues for co-production and co-development in defense, accelerated by China's assertive actions in the Indo-Pacific.

India's private sector is becoming a key driver of indigenous defense production, with successful joint projects (e.g., aircraft engines, MQ-9 drones) expected to strengthen the U.S.-India security relationship.
sources_accumulated.summary: This RAND Corporation commentary discusses boosting U.S.-India private sector defense industrial cooperation. It highlights India's evolving need to diversify its arms suppliers, driven by the "Make in India" initiative and Russia's inability to meet arms export commitments. The article emphasizes the U.S.-India Comprehensive Global and Strategic Partnership as a pathway for co-production and co-development, particularly in light of China's rise in the Indo-Pacific. It also notes the emerging role of India's private sector in defense production and the potential for successful joint projects to further strengthen the security relationship.

sources_accumulated.title: Analysing India‚Äôs Defence Allocation in Budget 2026-27: Modernisation in the Shadow of Operation Sindoor
key_claims: India's Union Budget 2026-27 allocates a record Rs 7.85 lakh crore ($93.5 billion) to defense, representing a 15.19% increase, with a focus on modernization and self-reliance post-"Operation Sindoor."

Capital outlay saw a significant 21.8% increase, primarily directed towards technology-intensive assets, aircraft and aero engines, and R&D to enhance air superiority, maritime deterrence, and modernize ground forces.
Despite the increased allocation, challenges such as pension burdens and slow procurement persist.
sources_accumulated.summary: This article analyzes India's Union Budget 2026-27, which allocates a historic Rs 7.85 lakh crore ($93.5 billion) to the Ministry of Defence, a 15.19% increase. The budget emphasizes modernization and self-reliance, particularly in the context of "Operation Sindoor," a recent military engagement. Key areas of increased capital outlay include technology-intensive assets, aircraft and aero engines, and R&D, aimed at enhancing air superiority, maritime deterrence, and modernizing ground forces. However, it also notes the persistent challenges of pension burdens and slow procurement.

sources_accumulated.title: Military budget of India - Wikipedia
key_claims: India's military budget funds the Indian Armed Forces, covering salaries, training, maintenance, and procurement of new technologies.
The Indian Army consumes over half of the defense budget, with much of this allocated to maintenance, salaries, and pensions rather than direct arms and ammunition procurement.

The overall defense budget includes allocations for all three services (Army, Navy, Air Force), ordnance factories, R&D, and capital expenses, with some border security forces and other related expenses categorized as unofficial.
sources_accumulated.summary: This Wikipedia article provides an overview of India's military budget, which funds the Indian Armed Forces, including salaries, training, equipment maintenance, and procurement of new technologies. It notes that the Indian Army accounts for over half of the total defense budget, with a significant portion going towards cantonments, salaries, and pensions rather than critical arms and ammunition. The budget also covers the navy, air force, ordnance factories, R&D, and capital outlay, with some civil defense and border security expenses falling under unofficial allocations.

state.investigation_summary:
# Investigation Summary: Indian Defence

## Executive Summary
India's defense strategy is characterized by an ambitious push for self-reliance and modernization, underpinned by significant budget increases, particularly in capital outlay for technology-intensive assets and indigenous production. Despite these efforts, India continues to grapple with a paradox of ambition versus reality, heavily relying on foreign suppliers for critical technologies and facing persistent challenges such as pension burdens and slow procurement processes. Concurrently, India is strengthening its international defense partnerships, notably with the U.S. and the EU, aiming to diversify its arms suppliers and enhance co-development, particularly in response to geopolitical shifts and assertive actions by countries like China.

## Key Findings
1.  **Defense Modernization and Capabilities:** India is prioritizing the enhancement of its defense capabilities through increased capital outlay, especially for technology-intensive assets, aircraft, aero engines, and R&D. The Union Budget 2026-27 allocated a record Rs 7.85 lakh crore ($93.5 billion) to defense, marking a 15.19% increase, with capital outlay surging by 21.8% to improve air superiority, maritime deterrence, and ground forces [5, 8]. This strategic shift is partly driven by lessons from recent military engagements such as "Operation Sindoor" [8]. The private sector's role in defense manufacturing is expanding, supporting the "Make in India" initiative to diversify arms suppliers and boost indigenous production [1, 7].
2.  **Challenges to Self-Reliance and Procurement:** Despite ambitions for self-reliance, India remains heavily dependent on foreign suppliers for critical technologies [1]. Structural issues like substantial pension burdens and slow procurement processes continue to challenge the effective utilization of increased defense allocations [8, 9]. The Indian Army, for instance, consumes over half of the defense budget, with a significant portion going to salaries and maintenance rather than direct arms procurement [9].
3.  **Strengthening International Partnerships:** India is actively diversifying its defense relationships. A new Security and Defence Partnership has been signed with the EU, establishing an annual dialogue for shared challenges [6]. The U.S.-India defense partnership is deepening, particularly through the "2025 Framework for the U.S.-India Major Defense Partnership," which elevates defense as a top priority and focuses on deterrence in the Indo-Pacific, implicitly targeting China [3]. This partnership promotes co-development and private sector collaboration, especially in advanced domains like space, cyber, and AI, with initiatives like INDUS-X [3, 7].
4.  **Strategic Motivations:** China's assertive actions in the Indo-Pacific and along India's borders have significantly accelerated U.S.-India defense cooperation [7]. India's defense diplomacy efforts, which include military engagements and training initiatives, aim to project power, though these are sometimes constrained by financial and material resources, limiting capacity-building compared to China [4].

## Verified Claims
*   The U.S. and India have a strong defense partnership, particularly regarding China, but have significant differences in defense spending, civilian governance, and industrial independence [2].
*   These divergences need to be addressed to achieve a deeper defense partnership [2].
*   The article focuses on the "what, where, and how" of deterrence coproduction, categorized into capability, geography, and interoperability [2].
*   India's Union Budget 2026-27 significantly increases defense allocation by 15.18%, reinforcing self-reliance and modernization [5].
*   Capital outlay for defense surged by 22% for capability enhancement and procurement of next-generation platforms and infrastructure [5].
*   The budget demonstrates a commitment to indigenous defense production (reaching INR 1.54 lakh crore) and investment in future-focused technologies [5].
*   The EU and India have signed a new Security and Defence Partnership [6].
*   This partnership will be implemented through an annual EU-India Security and Defence Dialogue and aims to strengthen existing cooperation [6].
*   The partnership is a key component of the new Joint EU-India Comprehensive Strategic Agenda, focusing on shared challenges and threats [6].
*   India is actively seeking to diversify its arms suppliers, moving away from its traditional reliance on countries like Russia, driven by the "Make in India" initiative [7].
*   The U.S.-India Comprehensive Global and Strategic Partnership offers avenues for co-production and co-development in defense, accelerated by China's assertive actions in the Indo-Pacific [7].
*   India's private sector is becoming a key driver of indigenous defense production, with successful joint projects (e.g., aircraft engines, MQ-9 drones) expected to strengthen the U.S.-India security relationship [7].
*   India aims for defense self-reliance but still heavily relies on foreign suppliers for critical technologies [1].
*   The private sector's role in defense manufacturing is expanding [1].
*   Bridging the gap in self-reliance requires sustained investment in R&D, a deeper industrial ecosystem, and efficient procurement [1].
*   The 2025 Framework for the U.S.-India Major Defense Partnership elevates defense as a top priority in their relationship [3].
*   The agreement explicitly focuses on deterrence in the Indo-Pacific, with an implicit shared adversary (China) [3].
*   The partnership is deepening in advanced domains like space, cyber, and AI, and encourages co-development and private sector collaboration through initiatives like INDUS-X [3].
*   India's Union Budget 2026-27 allocates a record Rs 7.85 lakh crore ($93.5 billion) to defense, representing a 15.19% increase, with a focus on modernization and self-reliance post-"Operation Sindoor" [8].
*   Capital outlay saw a significant 21.8% increase, primarily directed towards technology-intensive assets, aircraft and aero engines, and R&D to enhance air superiority, maritime deterrence, and modernize ground forces [8].
*   Despite the increased allocation, challenges such as pension burdens and slow procurement persist [8].
*   India employs defense diplomacy to project power via military engagements and training [4].
*   Resource constraints (financial and material) limit the scale and sustainability of India's military engagements [4].
*   India's capacity-building efforts remain modest compared to China's due to these limitations [4].
*   India's military budget funds the Indian Armed Forces, covering salaries, training, maintenance, and procurement of new technologies [9].
*   The Indian Army consumes over half of the defense budget, with much of this allocated to maintenance, salaries, and pensions rather than direct arms and ammunition procurement [9].
*   The overall defense budget includes allocations for all three services (Army, Navy, Air Force), ordnance factories, R&D, and capital expenses, with some border security forces and other related expenses categorized as unofficial [9].

## Unverified/Disputed Claims
No claims available for verification.

## Bias Assessment
Overall bias score: 1.9/10 (Neutral / Balanced)
The investigation included a balanced mix of sources, including analytical reports from think tanks, official government announcements, and general informational articles. While some sources showed a slight positive bias towards strengthening partnerships (e.g., U.S.-India cooperation), the majority maintained a neutral stance by presenting both India's ambitions and the inherent challenges and limitations. This diversity in perspectives contributes to a largely neutral and comprehensive overview.

## Timeline
| Date | Event | Sources |
|------|-------|---------|
| 1995-01-01 | U.S.-India Defense Agreement established as an "important part" of the relationship. | [3] |
| 2005-01-01 | U.S.-India Defense Agreement established as an "element" of the relationship. | [3] |
| 2014-01-01 | Modi government takes office in India, with defense budget then at Rs 2.29 lakh crore. | [8] |
| 2015-01-01 | U.S.-India Defense Agreement established as a "key component" of the relationship. | [3] |
| 2017-01-01 | Chinese incursions began along India's border. | [7] |
| 2023-01-01 | U.S.-India Advanced Domains Defense Dialogue takes place (continued into 2024). | [3] |
| 2024-10-25 | China and India reach an agreement to pull back forces in disputed border areas. | [7] |
| 2025-02-01 | EU and India sign a new Security and Defence Partnership. | [6] |
| 2025-05-01 | India-Pakistan war occurs, leading to introspection over defense capability gaps. | [3] |
| 2025-10-31 | "2025 Framework for the U.S.-India Major Defense Partnership" is signed in Kuala Lumpur. | [3] |
| 2025-01-01 | India's Defense Budget for FY 2025-26. | [5, 8] |
| 2026-02-01 | India's Union Budget 2026-27 is published, significantly increasing defense allocation. | [5] |
| 2026-02-03 | Analysis of India's Union Budget 2026-27 published, discussing modernization post-"Operation Sindoor". | [8] |
| 2026-01-01 | India's Union Budget 2026-27 is in effect, with a record Rs 7.85 lakh crore allocated to defense. | [5, 8] |
| 2029-01-01 | Target year for India to achieve INR3 lakh crore in indigenous defense production and INR50,000 crore in exports. | [5] |

## Recommendations
*   **Investigate Procurement Reforms:** Further analysis into specific reforms being implemented or proposed to address the persistent issue of slow procurement processes.
*   **Detailed Breakdown of Indigenous Production:** A deeper dive into the specific sectors and technologies where indigenous defense production is seeing success or facing obstacles to meet the 2029 targets.
*   **Impact of Pension Burdens:** Quantify the exact impact of pension and salary burdens on India's ability to allocate funds to modernization and R&D.

## Sources

U.S.-India Divergence and Convergence on Defense Operationalization Concepts
============================================================================

The United States and India have developed a strong defense partnership in recent years, especially in relation to China. However, they have major differences to bridge: how much to spend on defense, the role of civilian governance, and the independence of their defense-industrial bases.

![Image 1](https://assets.cfr.org/images/w_1920/t_cfr_3_2/f_auto/v1758107842/2020-01-26T100348Z_616936142_RC2MNE9LD6PX_RTRMADP_3_INDIA-REPUBLICDAY_62613911e/2020-01-26T100348Z_616936142_RC2MNE9LD6PX_RTRMADP_3_INDIA-REPUBLICDAY_62613911e.jpg?_i=AA)

India‚Äôs ‚ÄúAkash‚Äù missiles, mounted on a truck, are displayed during Republic Day parade in New Delhi, India, January 26, 2020. REUTERS/Altaf Hussain

By experts and staff
--------------------

Published June 5, 2025 11:24 a.m.

### By

*   Sameer Lalwani Senior Advisor, Special Competitive Studies Project   

Table of Contents

[](https://www.cfr.org/)

Share

### Table of Contents

1.   [Endnotes](https://www.cfr.org/articles/us-india-divergence-and-convergence-defense-operationalization-concepts#chapter-endnotes)

_This memo is a part of CFR Expert Manjari Chatterjee Miller‚Äôs_[_project on India and the liberal international order_](https://www.cfr.org/articles/india-united-states-and-future-international-trade-order "https://www.cfr.org/articles/india-united-states-and-future-international-trade-order")_published by CFR‚Äôs_[_China Strategy Initiative_](https://www.cfr.org/initiative/china-strategy "https://www.cfr.org/initiative/china-strategy")_through its[China 360¬∞](https://www.cfr.org/initiative/china-strategy/china-360 "China 360¬∞") program._

Introduction
------------

Much of the writing on the U.S.-India defense partnership focuses on the convergence of their interests. The two countries align on defending a free and open Indo-Pacific (with freedom of navigation and overflight), deepening strategic technological cooperation, and countering the hegemony the People‚Äôs Republic of China in Asia. Yet they differ on how to pursue those interests‚Äîas well as the ideas and values that underpin them. Understanding their divergent approaches can help identify the potential limits of the relationship as well as how to bridge those differences for a deeper defense partnership between the two.

At its core, the objective of a defense partnership‚Äîeven one short of an alliance‚Äîis explicitly or implicitly to coproduce security for both parties, ideally by coproducing deterrence. If deterrence and security are the ends of the defense partnership, it is important to examine how the United States, its allies, and India differently approach the means and ways to those ends: the what, where, and how of deterrence coproduction. Those differences can be divided into three categories: capability (what), geography (where), and interoperability (how), each of which are underpinned by differently held ideas. Luckily for Washington and Delhi, those divergences are surmountable.

Capability
----------

One foundational requirement for producing security is the mobilization of resources, or more specifically, defense investment, and their conversion through organizational and technological processes to defense and deterrence applications.[1](https://www.cfr.org/articles/us-india-divergence-and-convergence-defense-operationalization-concepts#744a5964-ee2e-4861-8b65-c298f422fc72) Nearly all countries choose to do this in some capacity, but their investments range in scale and efficiency. Some countries exhibit alternative behaviors to balancing threats‚Äîsuch as bandwagoning, hiding, or transcending‚Äîwhich can free them to invest less or inefficiently in defense.[2](https://www.cfr.org/articles/us-india-divergence-and-convergence-defense-operationalization-concepts#d41926d3-6a95-4d4e-86b7-b14625d44942)Correspondingly, countries can prioritize other means of influence, such as relying more on diplomacy, taking a declared

Title: Don‚Äôt Call it a Comeback: Why US-India Relations are Due for a Rebound

URL Source: https://scsp222.substack.com/p/dont-call-it-a-comeback-why-us-india

Published Time: 2025-11-20T19:10:05+00:00

Markdown Content:
> _In this edition of the newsletter, senior advisor to SCSP, **Sameer Lalwani** makes the case for doubling down on the U.S.-India defense partnership and offers highlights from a track 1.5 India-X workshop SCSP hosted in New Delhi, in knowledge partnership with Carnegie India, on November 14, 2025._

On October 31, U.S. Secretary of War Pete Hegseth and Indian Defence Minister Rajnath Singh met in Kuala Lumpur to sign the ‚Äú2025 Framework for the U.S.-India Major Defense Partnership,‚Äù a landmark agreement outlining defense cooperation for the next decade. This agreement builds on significant progress on defense operational and industrial cooperation over the past year, despite being overshadowed at times by some political friction. In spite of the tensions over tariffs, Russian oil, and the aftermath of the India-Pakistan war in 2025, the deal proves that over the past years, U.S.-India defense cooperation has matured into the steadiest part of the strategic partnership, partly due to China‚Äôs aggression on India‚Äôs borders, and in part owing to the mutual trust built over two decades of accelerating military-to-military capability transfer, interoperability, and trust.

A [fact sheet](https://media.defense.gov/2025/Nov/13/2003820236/-1/-1/1/FACT-SHEET-FRAMEWORK-FOR-THE-US-INDIA-MAJOR-DEFENSE-PARTNERSHIP.PDF) laying out the ambitions of the agreement revealed several notable details and milestones.

*   **Prioritization**. First, the language of the agreement elevates defense as a top priority. In contrast to past 10-year agreements, defense has moved to center stage from ‚Äúan important part‚Äù ([1995](https://mealib.nic.in/?pdf2583?000)) to ‚Äúan element‚Äù ([2005](https://library.rumsfeld.com/doclib/sp/3211/2005-06-28%20New%20Framework%20for%20the%20US-India%20Defense%20Relationship.pdf)) to ‚Äúa key component‚Äù ([2015](https://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc949830/m2/1/high_res_d/2015-Defense-Framework.pdf)) to now ‚Äú_**[the](https://www.pib.gov.in/PressReleasePage.aspx?PRID=2184622)**_[major pillar](https://www.pib.gov.in/PressReleasePage.aspx?PRID=2184622)‚Äù (2025) in the U.S.-India relationship.

*   **Mission**. Second, for the first time in three decades, a U.S.-India defense framework uses the word ‚Äúdeterrence‚Äù as a primary goal of the relationship. Deterrence requires a target (or adversary) whose behavior we intend to shape, implying a _shared mission_. Combined with the first mention of the geography of this partnership ‚Äì ‚Äúa pillar of peace and security and an anchor of stability in the Indo-Pacific region‚Äù‚Äì this makes it very clear who the shared adversary is without explicit naming. This language provides a level of specificity that warrants deeper operational, technological, supply-chain, and defense trade cooperation sought by both sides.

*   **Density**. Third, there is a depth and density to the document that is nearly twice as long (8 pages) as previous agreements in 2015 (5 pages), 2005 (4 pages), and 1995 (3 pages). The agreement also breaks new ground with new focus on space, cyber, and artificial intelligence (building off the [Advanced Domains Defense Dialogue](https://www.war.gov/News/Releases/Release/Article/3408336/readout-of-the-inaugural-us-india-advanced-domains-defense-dialogue/) of 2023-24), as domains for interoperability as well as co-development.

*   **Complementarity**. Finally, the agreement‚Äôs commitment to ‚Äújoint development and production of defense capabilities‚Äù banks on complementarities between U.S. defense tech and India‚Äôs [trusted scale](https://www.heritage.org/defense/commentary/sustaining-american-military-dominance-indian-scale-why-the-us-and-india-need). It also doubles down on co-innovation efforts like the India-U.S. Defense Acceleration Ecosystem ([INDUS-X](https://www.diu.mil/india-u-s-defense-acceleration-ecosystem-indus-x)) ‚Äúto continue to facilitate private sector partnerships among U.S. and Indian companies, investors, and researchers, strengthening ties between American and Indian defense industrial ecosystems.‚Äù

[![Image 1](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!YiM7!,w_1456,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F2ec92ca9-d4d6-4d1f-bd54-accab4abf630_1600x900.jpeg)](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!YiM7!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F2ec92ca9-d4d6-4d1f-bd54-accab4abf630_1600x900.jpeg)

The rollout of the framework was well-timed, as last week, the SCSP team was in New Delhi for discussions on AI and defense technology, including a workshop, in knowledge partnership with Carnegie India, on ‚ÄúAdvancing INDUS-X: The Future of US‚ÄìIndia Defense Tech Cooperation.‚Äù There we he

Title: Union Budget 2026 - Defense sector Highlights

URL Source: https://www.ey.com/content/dam/ey-unified-site/ey-com/en-in/services/tax/union-budget-2026/ey-defense-sector-highlights.pdf

Published Time: Sun, 01 Feb 2026 19:38:10 GMT

Number of Pages: 10

Markdown Content:
#EYon Budget2026 

# Budget 2026 ‚Äì27: Reinforcing defence 

# capability growth through enhanced capital 

# allocation 

Pawan Khatter 

Partner and National Leader, 

Aerospace and Defense, 

EY India 

The Union Budget 2026 underscores India‚Äôs sharpened strategic focus on defence 

preparedness, with an expected significant increase in defence allocation that reinforces the 

twin imperatives of self -reliance and modernization. The Ministry of Defence has again 

emerged as one of the top -funded ministries, with total allocations rising by 15.18% over last 

year‚Äôs Budget Estimates (BE) to INR7.84 lakh crore (US$85.7 billion). 

A significant 22% surge in capital outlay to INR2.19 lakh crore (US$23.9 billion) with 

allocation of nearly two -thirds of it towards key segments notably aircraft and aero engines 

and other equipment signals a strong push toward capability enhancement and procurement 

of next -generation platforms and infrastructure. Complementing this, revenue expenditure 

has expanded to INR3.65 lakh crore (US$39.9 billion), a ~17% increase, ensuring robust 

support for operational readiness, troop sustenance and logistics. 

Notably, INR88,053 crore (US$9.62 billion) has been earmarked for repairs, stores and 

works, bringing the overall modernization envelope to INR3.07 lakh crore (US$33.55 

billion). India‚Äôs commitment to ‚Äò Atmanirbharta ‚Äô is visible, with indigenous defence production 

reaching INR1.54 lakh crore (US$16.8 billion), reflecting growing confidence in domestic 

capabilities and a growing defence industrial base. 

BCD exemption on imported components used in manufacturing aircraft parts to all 

manufacturers, and a dedicated BCD exemption for Defence PSUs importing raw materials 

for producing aircraft parts for MRO are welcome measures to lower input costs, stimulate 

domestic manufacturing and building a competitive and self -reliant defence value chain. 

This year‚Äôs Budget allocation deepens investment in future -focused technologies, domestic 

industry and operational readiness, advancing India‚Äôs steady march toward a future -ready force .

1 February 2026 

Tax Alert ‚Äì Key announcements 

of Union Budget 2026 #EYon Budget2026 

# How does the Budget impact 

# Defence sector? 

‚ñ™ Defence allocation is accounted for under four demands 

for grants: 

‚ñ™ Demand No 19 ‚Äì Ministry of Defence (Civil) 

‚ñ™ Demand No 20 ‚Äì Defence services (revenue)

response.content:
Title: Boosting U.S.-India Private Sector Defense Industrial Cooperation

URL Source: https://www.rand.org/pubs/commentary/2025/01/boosting-us-india-private-sector-defense-industrial.html

Published Time: 2025-01-14

Markdown Content:
A [recent meeting](https://www.orfonline.org/event/observer-research-foundation-and-rand-corporation-annual-dialogue) between U.S. and Indian experts on security and defense cooperation identified opportunities and challenges to furthering private sector defense collaboration between the United States and India in ways that advance the overall [security partnership](https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/the-press-office/2016/06/07/joint-statement-united-states-and-india-enduring-global-partners-21st).

During the meeting, it was evident that the Indian government is keen on reducing traditional reliance of its defense forces on specific countries and geographies for weaponry. Despite [historical ties](https://carnegieendowment.org/research/2022/09/russia-and-india-a-new-chapter?lang=en) and the current level of technical cooperation and technology transfer from Russia, Indian participants expressed an evolving need to diversify. The urgency of diversification was highlighted by Russia's struggle to meet arms export commitments following its invasion of Ukraine. Prime Minister Narendra Modi's [‚ÄúMake in India‚Äù](https://www.pmindia.gov.in/en/major_initiatives/make-in-india/) initiative, which combines a realistic assessment of external threats and the need to innovate at home, is driving this shift.

The emergence of the [U.S.-India Comprehensive Global and Strategic Partnership](https://in.usembassy.gov/joint-fact-sheet-the-united-states-and-india-continue-to-expand-comprehensive-and-global-strategic-partnership/) has provided natural pathways to strengthen avenues in co-production and co-development. The two nations nurtured a mutual and strategic partnership over the course of the last two decades, marked by increasing economic trade, political engagement and security cooperation.

The [rise of China](https://www.orfonline.org/expert-speak/chinas-rise-and-the-implications-for-the-indo-pacific) as a dominant power in the Indo-Pacific has further aligned U.S. and Indian interests. China's assertive actions in the South and East China seas as well as in the Indian Ocean threaten regional stability, posing potential conflict risks with the United States and India. Additionally, Chinese incursions along India's border since 2017 significantly altered bilateral relations, providing both countries with compelling reasons to cooperate.

While the recent [China-India agreement](https://www.indiatoday.in/india/story/india-china-border-disengagement-standoff-eastern-ladakh-lac-deal-army-2622893-2024-10-25) to pull back forces in the disputed border areas has reduced tensions, the durability of the reproachment remains to be seen. Regardless, India aims to strengthen ties with [major economies](https://www.orfonline.org/research/time-for-a-nuanced-debate-on-chinese-fdi) in [Asia](https://diplomatist.com/2024/11/30/india-and-southeast-asia-expanding-avenues-for-economic-engagement-sustainable-development/) and [Europe](https://economy-finance.ec.europa.eu/economic-forecast-and-surveys/economic-forecasts/autumn-2024-economic-forecast-gradual-rebound-adverse-environment/indias-economic-surge-regional-global-economic-player_en) to bolster its economy and assert sovereignty in its relations with all major powers. U.S. participants noted that stronger relations between India and other democracies fit with U.S. views on global security, enhanced by alliances that respect international laws and norms.

Although Indian arms production predominantly occurs in the [public sector](https://www.orfonline.org/research/india-s-defence-industry-achievements-and-challenges), the private sector is emerging as a key driver of indigenous defense production. Make in India mandates and co-production arrangements with foreign companies are expected to bolster private sector growth. Joint production of defense equipment, such as [aircraft engines](https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/defence/us-trust-in-india-led-to-approval-of-selling-americas-most-exquisite-jet-engine-technology-to-india-says-us-envoy-garcetti/articleshow/111882759.cms?from=mdr) and [MQ-9 drones](https://news.usni.org/2024/02/01/u-s-approves-potential-3-9b-mq-9b-uav-sale-to-india), exemplifies the expanding U.S.-India security relationship. A successful joint U.S.-India co-development of a major defense item could serve as a significant endorsement for future cooperative projects.

A successful joint U.S.-India co-development of a major defense item could serve as a significant endorsement for future cooperative projects.

Parallel to major defense systems projects, collaboration among start-up companies is seen as crucial. While venture capital for Indian start-ups is growing, it remains less robust than in the U.S. [Collaboration in the d

   üí° Key finding: "India is diversifying its defense suppliers through its 'Make in India' initiative, boosting private sector involvement and fostering co-production and co-development with the U.S. within their strategic partnership, especially given China's influence in the Indo-Pacific."

data.title: Boosting U.S.-India Private Sector Defense Industrial Cooperation
data.summary: This RAND Corporation commentary discusses boosting U.S.-India private sector defense industrial cooperation. It highlights India's evolving need to diversify its arms suppliers, driven by the "Make in India" initiative and Russia's inability to meet arms export commitments. The article emphasizes the U.S.-India Comprehensive Global and Strategic Partnership as a pathway for co-production and co-development, particularly in light of China's rise in the Indo-Pacific. It also notes the emerging role of India's private sector in defense production and the potential for successful joint projects to further strengthen the security relationship.
key_claims: India is actively seeking to diversify its arms suppliers, moving away from its traditional reliance on countries like Russia, driven by the "Make in India" initiative.
The U.S.-India Comprehensive Global and Strategic Partnership offers avenues for co-production and co-development in defense, accelerated by China's assertive actions in the Indo-Pacific.

India's private sector is becoming a key driver of indigenous defense production, with successful joint projects (e.g., aircraft engines, MQ-9 drones) expected to strengthen the U.S.-India security relationship.

response.content:
Title: Analysing India‚Äôs Defence Allocation in Budget 2026-27: Modernisation in the Shadow of Operation Sindoor

URL Source: https://www.cppr.in/archives/analysing-india-defence-budget-2026-27-post-operation-sindoor

Published Time: 2026-02-03T10:21:43+00:00

Markdown Content:
![Image 1](https://www.cppr.in/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/Gemini_Generated_Image_gqm17agqm17agqm1-1024x559.png)

AI Generated image

**Introduction**
----------------

The Union Budget 2026-27 has allocated a historic **Rs 7.85 lakh crore** (approximately $93.5 billion) to the Ministry of Defence, marking a significant **15.19% increase** over the previous year‚Äôs estimates (BE) of Rs 6.81 lakh crore. This allocation must be viewed through the lens of the Modi government‚Äôs long-term trajectory; since taking office in 2014, when the defence budget stood at roughly Rs 2.29 lakh crore, the outlay has more than tripled.

However, the context of this year‚Äôs budget is uniquely defined by the ‚Äúhistoric success‚Äù of **Operation Sindoor,**the recent military engagement that seemingly vindicated specific tactical investments while exposing gaps in broader strategic capabilities. While the government frames this budget as a ‚Äúpost-Operation Sindoor push‚Äù to consolidate gains, a critical examination reveals a tension between headline-grabbing hikes and the persistent structural issues of pension burdens and slow procurement. Understanding this allocation is not merely an accounting exercise but a necessity for grasping India‚Äôs readiness in a volatile neighbourhood where ‚Äúcollusive threats‚Äù from China and Pakistan are no longer theoretical but operational realities.

**Deep Dive: Capital Allocation and Modernization Priorities**
--------------------------------------------------------------

A granular analysis of the **Rs 2,19,306.47 crore** total capital outlay reveals a strategic shift toward technology-intensive assets, though the structural challenge of balancing manpower costs against modernization persists.

#### **Capital Expenditure (Capex) Growth**

The total capital allocation for the 2026-27 fiscal year stands at **Rs 2,19,306.47 crore**, representing a significant **21.8% increase** over the previous year‚Äôs Budget Estimate of **Rs 1,80,000.00 crore**. This increase is primarily distributed across the following key areas:

*   **Other Equipments:** This remains the largest single head for modernization, allocated **Rs 82,217.82 crore** (BE 2026-27), up from **Rs 63,099.03 crore** in the 2025-26 BE. This reflects a massive **30.3% increase** intended for network-centric warfare tools and ground-based hardware.
*   **Aircraft and Aero Engines:** This sector received **Rs 63,733.94 crore** for 2026-27, a substantial jump from the **Rs 48,614.06 crore** allocated in the 2025-26 BE. While the previous year‚Äôs spending was revised upward mid-year to over Rs 72,000 crore, the new BE sets a high baseline for consistent procurement of fighter jets and engines.
*   **Research and Development (R&D):** Spending under this head is set to rise to **Rs 17,250.25 crore**, compared to **Rs 14,923.82 crore** in the 2025-26 BE, indicating a continued push for indigenous technology under the _Atmanirbhar Bharat_
*   **Naval Fleet:** Modernization for the Navy‚Äôs fleet is allocated **Rs 25,023.63 crore**, a modest increase from the **Rs 24,390.95 crore** set in the previous BE.
*   **Joint Staff and Services:** Reflecting the government‚Äôs focus on theaterisation and jointness, the allocation for ‚ÄúJoint Staff‚Äù surged from **Rs 2,352.82 crore** (BE 2025-26) to **Rs 3,138.72 crore** (BE 2026-27).

#### **Significance to India‚Äôs Defence Preparedness**

The focused spending on these specific items addresses critical present-day challenges and lessons learned from recent operations:

*   **Air Superiority and Standoff Capability:** The **31% BE-to-BE increase** in the ‚ÄúAircraft and Aero Engines‚Äù head is essential for maintaining a high state of readiness following **Operation Sindoor**. It ensures the IAF has the necessary funds for large-scale acquisitions (like the 114 fighter jet proposal) and sustaining the Rafale fleet‚Äôs electronic warfare capabilities.
*   **Maritime Deterrence:** The steady funding for the **Naval Fleet** (Rs 25,023.63 crore) is significant for countering the growing presence of adversarial vessels in the Indian Ocean Region. It facilitates critical projects like the Project 75(I) submarine deal, which is vital for undersea surveillance.
*   **Modernizing Ground Forces:** The jump in ‚ÄúOther Equipments‚Äù to over **Rs 82,000 crore** is the primary driver for digitizing the Army, improving situational awareness through drones and sensors, and upgrading infantry systems for high-altitude warfare.
*   **Building a Strategic Ecosystem:** The increased R&D budget (over **Rs 17,000 crore**) and the **Rs 1,707.81 crore** allocated for technology development under ‚Äúmake procedures‚Äù signify a move toward reducing dependence on foreign supply chains, which

response.content:
Title: Military budget of India

URL Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_budget_of_India

Published Time: 2014-07-20T16:40:42Z

Markdown Content:
[![Image 1: Extended-protected article](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/8c/Extended-protection-shackle.svg/20px-Extended-protection-shackle.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Protection_policy#extended "This article is extended-confirmed-protected")

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

[![Image 2](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/INS_Vikramaditya_-_02.jpg/330px-INS_Vikramaditya_-_02.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:INS_Vikramaditya_-_02.jpg)

Indian Navy [carrier battle group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carrier_battle_group "Carrier battle group") in transit led by aircraft carrier [INS _Vikramaditya_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/INS_Vikramaditya "INS Vikramaditya")

The military budget or defence budget of [India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India "India") is the portion of the overall budget of [Union budget of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_budget_of_India "Union budget of India") that is allocated for the funding of the [Indian Armed Forces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Armed_Forces "Indian Armed Forces"). The military budget finances employee salaries and training costs, maintenance of equipment and facilities, support of new or ongoing operations, and development and procurement of new technologies, weapons, equipment, and vehicles.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_budget_of_India#cite_note-1)

The [Indian Army](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Army "Indian Army") accounts for more than half of the total defence budget of India, with most of the expenditure going to the maintenance of [cantonments](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cantonments "Cantonments"), salaries and pensions, rather than critical arms and ammunition.[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_budget_of_India#cite_note-2)

Overview
--------

India's defence budget includes allocation for the three defence services: the army, [navy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Navy "Indian Navy") and [air force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Air_Force "Indian Air Force"). It also includes allocation for the [ordnance factories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ordnance_Factory_Board "Ordnance Factory Board"), research and development, and capital outlay. Additionally there are civil defence expenditures such as pensions. Unofficial expenditure includes expenses for four of the six [Central Armed Police Forces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Armed_Police_Forces "Central Armed Police Forces") responsible for border security. The [space program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISRO "ISRO") and atomic energy are funded separately.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_budget_of_India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBehera2015236–238-3)

India's official and unofficial defence allocation[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_budget_of_India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBehera2015236–238-3)| Official status | Category or Demand for Grants (DFGs) | DCE/DSE |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Unofficial | [Ministry of Defence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(India) "Ministry of Defence (India)") (Canteen Store Department, MOD Secretariat, [Coast Guard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Coast_Guard "Indian Coast Guard"), [J&K Light Infantry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_Light_Infantry "Jammu and Kashmir Light Infantry")) | Defence Civil (DCE) |
| Pensions and other benefits |
| Official defence budget | Operating expenses | Army (including the [National Cadet Corps](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Cadet_Corps_(India) "National Cadet Corps (India)") (NCC), Director General of Quality Assurance (DGQA), [Military Farms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_Farms_Service "Military Farms Service") and Ex-Servicemen Contributory Health Scheme) | Defence Services (DSE) |
| Navy (Joint Staff) |
| Air Force |
| [Ordnance Factories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ordnance_Factories "Ordnance Factories") |
| [Defence Research and Development Organisation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defence_Research_and_Development_Organisation "Defence Research and Development Organisation") (DRDO) |
| Capital expense | Capital outlay (Capital expenditure of all services including the NCC, Ordnance Factories and DGQA) |
| Unofficial | [Border Roads Organisation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Border_Roads_Organisation "Border Roads Organisation"), [Assam Rifles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Rifles "Assam Rifles"), [Border Security Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Border_Security_Force "Border Security Force"), [Indo-Tibetan Border Police](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-Tibetan_Border_Police "Indo-Tibetan Border Police"), [Sashastra Seema Bal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sashastra_Seema_Bal "Sashastra Seema Bal"), border management, CAPF construction, b

The budget also covers the navy, air force, ordnance factories, R&D, and capital outlay, with some civil defense and border security expenses falling under unofficial allocations.

# Investigation Summary: Indian Defence

## Executive Summary
India's defense strategy is characterized by an ambitious push for self-reliance and modernization, underpinned by significant budget increases, particularly in capital outlay for technology-intensive assets and indigenous production. Despite these efforts, India continues to grapple with a paradox of ambition versus reality, heavily relying on foreign suppliers for critical technologies and facing persistent challenges such as pension burdens and slow procurement processes. Concurrently, India is strengthening its international defense partnerships, notably with the U.S. and the EU, aiming to diversify its arms suppliers and enhance co-development, particularly in response to geopolitical shifts and assertive actions by countries like China.

## Key Findings
1.  **Defense Modernization and Capabilities:** India is prioritizing the enhancement of its defense capabilities through increased capital outlay, especially for technology-intensive assets, aircraft, aero engines, and R&D. The Union Budget 2026-27 allocated a record Rs 7.85 lakh crore ($93.5 billion) to defense, marking a 15.19% increase, with capital outlay surging by 21.8% to improve air superiority, maritime deterrence, and ground forces [5, 8]. This strategic shift is partly driven by lessons from recent military engagements such as "Operation Sindoor" [8]. The private sector's role in defense manufacturing is expanding, supporting the "Make in India" initiative to diversify arms suppliers and boost indigenous production [1, 7].
2.  **Challenges to Self-Reliance and Procurement:** Despite ambitions for self-reliance, India remains heavily dependent on foreign suppliers for critical technologies [1]. Structural issues like substantial pension burdens and slow procurement processes continue to challenge the effective utilization of increased defense allocations [8, 9]. The Indian Army, for instance, consumes over half of the defense budget, with a significant portion going to salaries and maintenance rather than direct arms procurement [9].
3.  **Strengthening International Partnerships:** India is actively diversifying its defense relationships. A new Security and Defence Partnership has been signed with the EU, establishing an annual dialogue for shared challenges [6]. The U.S.-India defense partnership is deepening, particularly through the "2025 Framework for the U.S.-India Major Defense Partnership," which elevates defense as a top priority and focuses on deterrence in the Indo-Pacific, implicitly targeting China [3]. This partnership promotes co-development and private sector collaboration, especially in advanced domains like space, cyber, and AI, with initiatives like INDUS-X [3, 7].
4.  **Strategic Motivations:** China's assertive actions in the Indo-Pacific and along India's borders have significantly accelerated U.S.-India defense cooperation [7]. India's defense diplomacy efforts, which include military engagements and training initiatives, aim to project power, though these are sometimes constrained by financial and material resources, limiting capacity-building compared to China [4].

## Verified Claims
*   The U.S. and India have a strong defense partnership, particularly regarding China, but have significant differences in defense spending, civilian governance, and industrial independence [2].
*   These divergences need to be addressed to achieve a deeper defense partnership [2].
*   The article focuses on the "what, where, and how" of deterrence coproduction, categorized into capability, geography, and interoperability [2].
*   India's Union Budget 2026-27 significantly increases defense allocation by 15.18%, reinforcing self-reliance and modernization [5].
*   Capital outlay for defense surged by 22% for capability enhancement and procurement of next-generation platforms and infrastructure [5].
*   The budget demonstrates a commitment to indigenous defense production (reaching INR 1.54 lakh crore) and investment in future-focused technologies [5].
*   The EU and India have signed a new Security and Defence Partnership [6].
*   This partnership will be implemented through an annual EU-India Security and Defence Dialogue and aims to strengthen existing cooperation [6].
*   The partnership is a key component of the new Joint EU-India Comprehensive Strategic Agenda, focusing on shared challenges and threats [6].
*   India is actively seeking to diversify its arms suppliers, moving away from its traditional reliance on countries like Russia, driven by the "Make in India" initiative [7].
*   The U.S.-India Comprehensive Global and Strategic Partnership offers avenues for co-production and co-development in defense, accelerated by China's assertive actions in the Indo-Pacific [7].
*   India's private sector is becoming a key driver of indigenous defense production, with successful joint projects (e.g., aircraft engines, MQ-9 drones) expected to strengthen the U.S.-India security relationship [7].
*   India aims for defense self-reliance but still heavily relies on foreign suppliers for critical technologies [1].
*   The private sector's role in defense manufacturing is expanding [1].
*   Bridging the gap in self-reliance requires sustained investment in R&D, a deeper industrial ecosystem, and efficient procurement [1].
*   The 2025 Framework for the U.S.-India Major Defense Partnership elevates defense as a top priority in their relationship [3].
*   The agreement explicitly focuses on deterrence in the Indo-Pacific, with an implicit shared adversary (China) [3].
*   The partnership is deepening in advanced domains like space, cyber, and AI, and encourages co-development and private sector collaboration through initiatives like INDUS-X [3].
*   India's Union Budget 2026-27 allocates a record Rs 7.85 lakh crore ($93.5 billion) to defense, representing a 15.19% increase, with a focus on modernization and self-reliance post-"Operation Sindoor" [8].
*   Capital outlay saw a significant 21.8% increase, primarily directed towards technology-intensive assets, aircraft and aero engines, and R&D to enhance air superiority, maritime deterrence, and modernize ground forces [8].
*   Despite the increased allocation, challenges such as pension burdens and slow procurement persist [8].
*   India employs defense diplomacy to project power via military engagements and training [4].
*   Resource constraints (financial and material) limit the scale and sustainability of India's military engagements [4].
*   India's capacity-building efforts remain modest compared to China's due to these limitations [4].
*   India's military budget funds the Indian Armed Forces, covering salaries, training, maintenance, and procurement of new technologies [9].
*   The Indian Army consumes over half of the defense budget, with much of this allocated to maintenance, salaries, and pensions rather than direct arms and ammunition procurement [9].
*   The overall defense budget includes allocations for all three services (Army, Navy, Air Force), ordnance factories, R&D, and capital expenses, with some border security forces and other related expenses categorized as unofficial [9].

## Unverified/Disputed Claims
No claims available for verification.

## Bias Assessment
Overall bias score: 1.9/10 (Neutral / Balanced)
The investigation included a balanced mix of sources, including analytical reports from think tanks, official government announcements, and general informational articles. While some sources showed a slight positive bias towards strengthening partnerships (e.g., U.S.-India cooperation), the majority maintained a neutral stance by presenting both India's ambitions and the inherent challenges and limitations. This diversity in perspectives contributes to a largely neutral and comprehensive overview.

## Timeline
| Date | Event | Sources |
|------|-------|---------|
| 1995-01-01 | U.S.-India Defense Agreement established as an "important part" of the relationship. | [3] |
| 2005-01-01 | U.S.-India Defense Agreement established as an "element" of the relationship. | [3] |
| 2014-01-01 | Modi government takes office in India, with defense budget then at Rs 2.29 lakh crore. | [8] |
| 2015-01-01 | U.S.-India Defense Agreement established as a "key component" of the relationship. | [3] |
| 2017-01-01 | Chinese incursions began along India's border. | [7] |
| 2023-01-01 | U.S.-India Advanced Domains Defense Dialogue takes place (continued into 2024). | [3] |
| 2024-10-25 | China and India reach an agreement to pull back forces in disputed border areas. | [7] |
| 2025-02-01 | EU and India sign a new Security and Defence Partnership. | [6] |
| 2025-05-01 | India-Pakistan war occurs, leading to introspection over defense capability gaps. | [3] |
| 2025-10-31 | "2025 Framework for the U.S.-India Major Defense Partnership" is signed in Kuala Lumpur. | [3] |
| 2025-01-01 | India's Defense Budget for FY 2025-26. | [5, 8] |
| 2026-02-01 | India's Union Budget 2026-27 is published, significantly increasing defense allocation. | [5] |
| 2026-02-03 | Analysis of India's Union Budget 2026-27 published, discussing modernization post-"Operation Sindoor". | [8] |
| 2026-01-01 | India's Union Budget 2026-27 is in effect, with a record Rs 7.85 lakh crore allocated to defense. | [5, 8] |
| 2029-01-01 | Target year for India to achieve INR3 lakh crore in indigenous defense production and INR50,000 crore in exports. | [5] |

## Recommendations
*   **Investigate Procurement Reforms:** Further analysis into specific reforms being implemented or proposed to address the persistent issue of slow procurement processes.
*   **Detailed Breakdown of Indigenous Production:** A deeper dive into the specific sectors and technologies where indigenous defense production is seeing success or facing obstacles to meet the 2029 targets.
*   **Impact of Pension Burdens:** Quantify the exact impact of pension and salary burdens on India's ability to allocate funds to modernization and R&D.

## Sources
[1] https://www.orfonline.org/research/ambition-vs-reality-the-paradox-of-india-s-defence-spending - Ambition vs Reality: The Paradox Of India's Defence Spending
[2] https://www.cfr.org/articles/us-india-divergence-and-convergence-defense-operationalization-concepts - U.S.-India Divergence and Convergence on Defense Operationalization Concepts | Council on Foreign Relations
[3] https://scsp222.substack.com/p/dont-call-it-a-comeback-why-us-india - Don't Call it a Comeback: Why US-India Relations are Due for a Rebound
[4] https://www.cescube.com/vp-india-s-defence-diplomacy-projecting-power-through-military-engagements-and-training-initiatives - India‚Äôs Defence Diplomacy: Projecting Power through Military Engagements and Training Initiatives
[5] https://www.ey.com/content/dam/ey-unified-site/ey-com/en-in/services/tax/union-budget-2026/ey-defense-sector-highlights.pdf - Union Budget 2026 - Defense sector Highlights
[6] https://www.eeas.europa.eu/eeas/security-and-defence-eu-and-india-sign-security-defence-partnership_en - Security and Defence: EU and India sign security & defence partnership | EEAS
[7] https://www.rand.org/pubs/commentary/2025/01/boosting-us-india-private-sector-defense-industrial.html - Boosting U.S.-India Private Sector Defense Industrial Cooperation
[8] https://www.cppr.in/archives/analysing-india-defence-budget-2026-27-post-operation-sindoor - Analysing India‚Äôs Defence Allocation in Budget 2026-27: Modernisation in the Shadow of Operation Sindoor

*   The overall defense budget includes allocations for all three services (Army, Navy, Air Force), ordnance factories, R&D, and capital expenses, with some border security forces and other related expenses categorized as unofficial [9].
